article.title: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat
article.abstract: An inflatable lunar/Mars analog habitat (ILMAH), simulated closed system isolated by HEPA filtration, mimics International Space Station (ISS) conditions and future human habitation on other planets except for the exchange of air between outdoor and indoor environments. The ILMAH was primarily commissioned to measure physiological, psychological, and immunological characteristics of human inhabiting in isolation, but it was also available for other studies such as examining its microbiological aspects.
technologies: potato dextrose agar plate counts method

technologies_detail.text: potato dextrose agar plate counts method
technologies_detail.normalized: potato dextrose agar plate counts method

article.insights_summary: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat. The study found that human presence led to changes in fungal community structure and diversity. The results suggest that proper maintenance protocols are required to preserve the habitat from deteriorating and keep it safe for its inhabitants.
article.acknowledgments: The authors are grateful to the three student crews that participated in this program.
